subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... Please note the word originally .  QS was originally designed around RP, and RP uses these three sounds in those three words.  That doesn t mean that
messageBody:
paulhtremblay scripsit:

> > There can be no material doubt that they referred originally to the
> > IPA's [A], [O], and [Q] (in the SAMPA transcription of IPA into ASCII),
>
> Of course there can be tons of doubt because not everyone speaks
> British English.

Please note the word "originally". QS was originally designed around
RP, and RP uses these three sounds in those three words. That
doesn't mean that everyone knows what the sounds are, to be sure,
especially those who make no such three-way distinction -- that is,
all of North America. Roughly speaking, Canada merges Ah and Awe
but keeps Ox separate, most of the eastern U.S. merges Ah and Ox
and keeps Awe separate, and most of the western U.S. merges all three.

> How can you possibly say there is no doubt when other users have
> expressed confusion and when you know that no everyone speaks British
> English?

There is no doubt about the above historical and phonological facts.

> Well, pleae understand. How do you expect me to follow your posts when
> you make such contradictions?

I don't.

--
John Cowan <cowan@...> http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
It's like if you meet an really old, really rich guy covered in liver
spots and breathing with an oxygen tank, and you say, "I want to be
rich, too, so I'm going to start walking with a cane and I'm going to
act crotchety and I'm going to get liver disease. --Wil Shipley
